Different selection of cationic ligands, metal halides, and the
number of layers of inorganic materials will lead to the change of
crystal structure and optical properties of 2D perovskite
Moreover, these organic ligands have a great influence on the
electronic properties of inorganic layer by twisting the soft
Therefore, it is important to underÂ­
stand the relationship among the material constituents, crystal
structures, and optoelectronic properties, so that one can
tune the bandgap, transport performance, and charge carrier
dynamics and eventually fabricate excellent optoelectronic
The first 2D layered lead halide perovskite (C
was obtained by Dolzhenko et al. in 1986.
shows the ability to intercalate with appropriate organic solÂ­
vents through weak interaction. Another 2D perovskite
was reported by Ishihara et al.,
is similar to a quantum well (QW) structure where inorganic
layers are separated by insulating organic layers. Over the years,
2D organicâinorganic hybrid halide perovskites have been
known by researchers, but they have not achieved the same
While a number of reviews have been published about 2D
perovskites regarding their structure and application in solar
we here summarize the recent advances in the synÂ­
thesis of 2D metal halide perovskites, highlight their unique
tunable bandgap, narrowband fluorescence, and white light
radiation properties, discuss the charge carriersâ transport, and
focus more on LEDs. We hope that this review will stimulate
more efforts in this field, including materialsâ preparation and
Dimensions of perovskites can be controlled by selecting
different organic ligands and metal halides. The orientation
of the inorganic thin layers is dependent on the geometry
and noncovalent bond interaction of spatial cations, and the
number of inorganic layers is directly determined by the stoiÂ­

in the City University of Hong Kong. His research interests
